title: Medicaid Enrollment Surged During Covid-19 Pandemic, Report Shows
summary: Nearly 9.9 million people enrolled in Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program. More than 80 million people-a record number-have health coverage through Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program, as enrollments surged due to Covid-19, according to new data released Monday by the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

title: Carl Nassib Becomes First Active NFL Player to Come Out as Gay
summary: The Las Vegas Raiders defensive end made the announcement on Instagram, eliciting statements of support from his team and the NFL. Las Vegas Raiders defensive end Carl Nassib on Monday became the first NFL player to come out as gay while still playing in the league, a significant moment in an American sport long identified with traditional ideas of masculinity.

title: Manhattan District Attorney Candidates Sprint to Finish
summary: The race has become contentious in recent days as the two leading candidates trade punches. The eight candidates for Manhattan district attorney spent the final day before the Democratic primary election trying to sway undecided voters in a race with no clear front-runner.

title: Court Revives Challenge to California Mandate on Women Board Members
summary: Federal judges say shareholder may sue over state's 2018 law that requires public companies in California to have women directors. A federal appeals court ruled that an investor may sue California over a 2018 law requiring publicly traded companies with headquarters in the state to include at least one woman on their boards.

title: From Covid to Comeback
summary: Rahm wins the U.S. Open. Plus, Federal Reserve officials on the brink of discovering the pandemic emergency is over.. "Investors are growing more fearful of a Fed mistake," says a headline at corporate cousin Marketwatch. "A survey now finds 'central bank policy error' is the third biggest risk to the market," writes Steve Goldstein. But he also notes that "higher-than-expected inflation and bond yields" were identified as the biggest risk, which many may eventually count in the category of Fed policy errors. The survey comes from Deutsche Bank , which finds such concerns rising since April.

title: The Attack on an Alzheimer's Drug
summary: Progressives suddenly discover federal spending they don't like.. Public-health and media critics failed to stop federal approval of Aduhelm, Biogen 's new drug for Alzheimer's. So now they're mounting an assault on the drug's cost to stop Medicare from paying for it. Their sudden and rare concern for the federal fisc is illuminating, and not in a good way.

title: 'Phase Two' Iran Talks Go Kaput
summary: The Biden team continues to misjudge Tehran at every turn.. So much for "phase two" of the Iran nuclear talks. Iran's president-elect Ebrahim Raisi won't take office until August, but on Monday he announced his government won't negotiate over ballistic missiles or its support for proxies destabilizing the Middle East.

title: Justice Gorsuch's Antitrust Tutorial
summary: In brushing back the NCAA, he and the Supreme Court offer good advice to other judges.. Congress is gearing up to pass new antitrust laws that scrap the consumer-welfare standard that has long held sway under the law. The Supreme Court weighed in Monday with a timely reminder that courts still need to keep consumer benefit top of mind.

title: Supreme Court Rejects NCAA's Tight Limits on Athlete Benefits, Compensation
summary: The court rules the NCAA violated antitrust law by limiting schools from competing for player talent by offering better benefits. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that strict NCAA limits on compensating college athletes violate U.S. antitrust law, a decision that could have broad ramifications for the future of college sports.

title: NYC Primary: Your Guide to the Election, Candidates
summary: Thirteen candidates are on the ballot in Tuesday's Democratic primary; a winner will be chosen through ranked-choice voting. New York City voters were at the polls on Tuesday for the mayoral primaries, which, for the first time, use a ranked-choice voting system to pick the winner.

title: 'Iran's Perilous Pursuit of Nuclear Weapons' Review: In Tehran's Nuclear Archive
summary: A cache of papers collected during Mossad's 2018 raid on Iran reveals the true extent of the Islamic nation's nuclear ambitions.. The Biden administration is working hard to re-enter the 2015 Iran nuclear deal. Readers of David Albright's "Iran's Perilous Pursuit of Nuclear Weapons," however, will realize that it is Washington, not Tehran, that is pursuing a truly perilous course.

title: Fed's Williams Not Ready to Pare Aid, but Other Officials Talk Tapering
summary: New York Fed chief John Williams says the central bank is a ways off from achieving its job and inflation goals. Federal Reserve Bank of New York leader John Williams said he isn't ready for the U.S. central bank to dial back the support it is giving the economy amid uncertainty about the recovery from the pandemic.

title: 'Free' Money Can Make Life Worse
summary: Social workers, not check writers, address problems like substance abuse and domestic violence.. The left continues its push to do away with accountability in safety-net programs. title: Erratic Data Is an Economic Symptom of the Pandemic
summary: Among the conundrums: How do you seasonally adjust for a socially distanced Christmas?. Confused about the state of the U.S. economy? It's no wonder. One day a strong report comes in on jobs or gross domestic product. Then another data release on unfilled jobs or inflation paints a different picture.

title: Expand the Human Rights Council
summary: Why not simply make each U.N. member state an automatic member?. Geneva

summary: Asset managers push for more information; energy, transportation companies say climate-change risks aren't easily measured. WASHINGTON-The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to require public companies to disclose more information about how they respond to threats linked to climate change-and businesses are gearing up for a fight.

title: Bitcoin Price Extends Drop After China Intensifies Crypto Crackdown
summary: Authorities order Ant Group and state banks to root out cryptocurrency-related activities. The price of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies slid Monday after China's central bank ordered the country's largest banks and payment processors to take a more active role in curbing cryptocurrency trading and related activities.

title: New York City Police Increase Payments for Anticrime Tips
summary: Initiative announced after a weekend in which NYPD recorded 19 shootings and two homicides. The New York Police Department is increasing payments for crime tips as it seeks to end an increase in shootings and homicides, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said Monday.

title: Economy Is Showing Sustained Progress, Powell Says
summary: Fed chairman sees inflationary pressures easing after pandemic-related supply bottlenecks fade. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said Monday that job growth should pick up in coming months and temporary inflation pressures should ease as the economy continues to recover from the effects of the pandemic.

title: Donald Trump's Former Bodyguard Under Scrutiny in New York Probe
summary: Matthew Calamari, now the Trump Organization's chief operating officer, has hired his own attorney as prosecutors investigate the company's employee perks. New York prosecutors are investigating whether a top Trump Organization executive, Matthew Calamari, received tax-free fringe benefits, as part of their probe into whether former President Donald Trump's company and its employees illegally avoided paying taxes on such perks, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: 'The Golden Casket' by Modest Mouse Review: Float On Past the Noise
summary: The rock band's seventh LP teems with experimental sound, but that's not where its value lies..

summary: Here's how to avoid getting stuck if your scheduled flight gets axed as airlines make last-minute changes. summary: Investors assess the prospects of higher economic growth, inflation and rising interest rates. U.S. stocks rallied Monday, lifting the Dow Jones Industrial Average by more than 550 points, as shares of everything from banks to manufacturers climbed.

title: Lordstown Motors Executives Sold Stock Ahead of Reporting Results
summary: A board special committee concluded the share sales 'were made for reasons unrelated to the performance of the company'. Several top executives at Lordstown Motors Corp. sold off chunks of stock in the electric-truck startup ahead of reporting financial results, according to regulatory filings disclosing the transactions.

title: Chinese Port Logjam Threatens Christmas Shipping Rush
summary: Industry executives say a backlog of ships on the water and an estimated 350,000 containers at docks will further rattle global supply chains deep into the year. The latest obstacle hitting global shipping is likely to jolt trade flows for several more weeks and could delay shipments heading into the year-end holiday shopping season.

title: Tokyo Olympics to Allow Spectators at Summer Games
summary: Organizers will permit up to 10,000 fans at each event but new headaches emerged over the imposition of pandemic protocols for athletes from hard-hit countries. TOKYO-The Summer Olympics in Tokyo will include up to 10,000 Japanese spectators at each event, organizers said, even as new headaches emerged over the imposition of pandemic protocols for athletes from hard-hit countries.

title: The Federal Reserve Is Facing Troubled Waters
summary: The Fed could be reined in by having it commit to conduct monetary policy in keeping with basic economic principles.. In his June 16 letter responding to Michael T. Belongia and Peter N. Ireland's "The Fed's Duty Is to the Economy, Not 'Equity'" (op-ed, June 10), Prof. Stephen Happel is correct to suggest "the time has come to rein in the power of the Fed." However, his suggestion that it be done by having the Fed adopt a monetary-policy rule, such as Milton Friedman's money-growth rule or John B. Taylor's interest-rate rule, isn't correct.

title: Readers Sing Praises of Trees Big and Small
summary: Trees are wonderfully therapeutic, and that can apply whether the trees are monumental or miniature.. A behemoth banyan can provide "The Benefits of a Tree Friend" (Personal Journal, June 16) and so can a bitty bonsai. Bonsai is a venerable and ancient art in which strong images of powerful trees are replicated in miniature, growing in shallow pots. I find relaxing pleasure in watering and eyeing my many 8-to-12-inch bonsai trees every day. Occasionally, after lengthy observation, I adjust the setting of one ever so slightly or gently clip a nub of errant twig.

title: Civil Servants Need More Time in Private Life
summary: Allow civil servants to spend two or three years in the private sector and be guaranteed re-entry to the civil service without loss of GS grade.. Two contributions to "Why Liberals Dominate Federal Bureaucracy" (Letters, June 17) suggest to me one change that could help improve both identified problems. David Reynolds bemoans a corporate employee spending a few years in the Washington bureaucracy as "punching a ticket" in his or her rise up the private career ladder. Mark Adams's concerns are with a protected class of civil servants. A policy change that could improve this situation would be to allow civil servants to spend two or three years in the private sector and be guaranteed re-entry to the civil service without loss of GS grade. It should be seen as a career enhancer, a step up the government's career ladder. It should be limited to the profit-making sector; civil servants are already familiar with a nonprofit, debt-ridden organization. The civil servants would benefit by seeing, day after day, what the effect of the growing jungle of regulations does to companies. There would need to be certain restrictions: no lobbying, no direct contact with the agency that person had been serving in, and so on.

title: Hey, Prince Philip Really Did Fight Fascists in Battle
summary: His actions did more to defeat fascism than any of the carping cant from self-important Twitterati.. Jerome Marcus's depressing June 12 letter hinting at modern writers condemning the Allies as "patriarchists" reminded me of some of the more uncharitable obituaries of the recently departed Prince Philip, husband of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: Sanderson Farms Explores Sale
summary: Chicken producer has attracted interest from suitors including agricultural investment firm Continental Grain. Poultry giant Sanderson Farms Inc. is exploring a sale, according to people familiar with the matter, as demand for chicken products rises.

title: Meatpacking Industry Faces Overhaul Push in Washington
summary: New rules, legislation would revamp markets for livestock, poultry. The American meatpacking industry faces stricter oversight in Washington, as lawmakers and regulators push an overhaul of the $213 billion sector following complaints about meat companies' alleged influence over markets and farmers.

title: U.S. to Miss June Target for Some Covid-19 Vaccine Donations
summary: Officials say delays are related to logistical challenges in countries set to receive vaccines. WASHINGTON-The White House on Monday detailed plans to allocate 55 million Covid-19 vaccine doses it is donating overseas, saying the shipments would likely take longer than President Biden's initial target of sending them out by the end of June.

title: Long-Dated Treasurys Win Favor on Receding Inflation Bets
summary: Investors have been unwinding trades that bet on stronger economic growth and inflation. Investors have rushed into longer-dated Treasurys in a bet that the Federal Reserve will act more quickly against inflation, leading to slower growth and lower interest rates in the longer term.

summary: The streaming giant announces agreement to have multiple new films made by Spielberg's production company Amblin Partners. summary: James Vorley gets a year and a day for manipulating metals prices through spoofing.

title: Jordan's Royal Rift Spills Into Court as Men Face Sedition Charges
summary: Two men were indicted in connection to an alleged plot to replace the king with his younger half-brother, Prince Hamzah bin Hussein. A public rift between Jordan's King Abdullah II and his younger half-brother entered a new stage, as two of the prince's alleged co-conspirators appeared in court for the first time to face charges of sedition over their involvement in a purported plot to replace the monarch.

title: As U.S. Cruises Resume, Operators Outfit Ships With Contact-Tracing Tech

title: Work Flexibility Is Hardly a Holy Grail
summary: Surveys show many Americans aren't eager to return to the office, but companies have more to consider than just their feelings. Many of today's workers have landed the upper hand when it comes to where and when they work. But no one should get too comfortable.

title: The Pandemic Produces a Youth Movement in the Pool for Team USA
summary: Eight days of unpredictable, upset-filled racing at the U.S. Olympic Swim Trials produced a roster of unexpected swimmers heading to Tokyo. title: South America Is Now the World's Covid-19 Hot Spot
summary: Driving the surge are more infectious variants, low vaccination rates, weak healthcare systems and, in some cases, governments that gave up on controlling the virus. title: Tornado Touches Down in Chicago Suburb; Five in Hospital
summary: Sixteen homes declared uninhabitable amid more than 100 reports of property damage as storm hits in Naperville, Ill.. Five people were sent to the hospital and dozens of homes were damaged when a tornado touched down in the Chicago suburb of Naperville late Sunday, local officials said.

title: 'Jacket Required' No More? How the Pandemic Changed Dress Codes
summary: Le Bernardin in New York City was the latest 'jacket required' restaurant to chuck its formal policy. summary: U.S. is likely the top destination for foreign investment, according to the U.N., as businesses meet bounce in demand for everything from steel to pet food. summary: Lose weight with your own 30-day challenge, breathe deeply to shed stress and other tips for getting back to your pre-lockdown shape and self.. title: Don't Sweat Your Pandemic Résumé Gap
